Description: Lower body sherd (mended from two fragments) of Attic, probably black-figured, pottery open vessel, possibly a krater; interior glazed black; exterior, from top: pair of narrow black bands; silhouette decoration consisting of naked male figure (an eidolon?) running to right; single black line.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
There is no evidence of black figure related incision on the sherd.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 478, no. B832)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0235) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 95, pl. II, no. 33)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
